Install from NodeSource for (up to v8), I am on Disco Bungie and am running 12.10. I had to update my Kernel and install the ppa's for 12 from the Node API. There is a lot of info there and some frustration with the Ubuntu/ Snap Paridigm, it seems. None-the-less... This is also a very stable platform and almost never says no after you, sternly remind bash that you are root with sudo -s.... As far as the snap store- (I miss the good old days of browsing obscure repos with Aptitude...)  You can install Node (Webstorm, VSCode, Chromium, Mocha, etc. globally with sudo snap install $(Whatever) --classic. Also, with many of the apps that you might want, the distributor has usually already yelled at the developers to make their software Snap-Ubuntu compatible - Not so much for SUSE or CentOS/ Fedora people.... Otherwise, I would be on SUSE (Preferably Slackware, Honestly... but my eyes are starting to get too old to read all of that small text in the Terminal.
summary: A couple of hints for those having difficulties

description: Permission denied installing global dependencies. At least you should test it before publishing a workable product.
summary: Not working out of the box

description:
1. Back up your computer.
2. On the command line, in your home directory, create a directory for global installations:
 	mkdir ~/.npm-global
3. Configure npm to use the new directory path:
 	npm config set prefix '~/.npm-global'
4. In your preferred text editor, open or create a ~/.profile file and add this line:
 	export PATH=~/.npm-global/bin:$PATH
5. On the command line, update your system variables:
 	source ~/.profile
6. To test your new configuration, install a package globally without using sudo:
 	npm install -g jshint

description:
Pues eso, en teoria los snaps están para tener las apps más actualizadas pero su versión es la 12 y ya la hemos pasado con creces -> https://github.com/nodesource/distributions/blob/master/README.md

El problema es que muchos frameworks no funcionan si instalas esta, la solución que encontré es instalar curl -> sudo apt-get install curl y después la versión que consideres. En mi caso
curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_15.x | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs . Actualicen esto que es muy útil si está actualizado
